section.title: Past continuous
section.sectiontitle: We use was/were + verb + -ing to talk about actions or states in progress at a certain time in the past.
section.sectiontitle2: We also use it for actions or states in progress in the past when another action happened.
section.text3a: We were living in Dublin when we first met Ian.
section.text4a: I saw Mel when I was walking in town.

section.title: Past continuous
section.sectiontitle: In the negative, we use I/you/we/they weren't + verb + -ing and he/she/it wasn't + verb + -ing.
section.text1a: They weren't listening when I spoke to them.
section.text2a: She wasn't looking when she fell over.
section.sectiontitle2: In the question, we use were I/you/we/they + verb + -ing and was he/she/it + verb + -ing.
section.text4a: Was he working with you then? No, he wasn't.
